issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2 description) incorrectly states that PersonController methods take a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter. The template and the UML/other descriptions clearly expect Consumer<List<Person>> for PersonController methods. This copy-paste error in the problem text can confuse students about the expected generic type and which controller the sentence refers to.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the problem statement wording to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods. This clarifies the expected parameter types and avoids confusion caused by a copy-paste mistake.

issues.description: The template PersonService declares its collection as a List<Person> and the problem statement explicitly warns students not to change the attributes of PersonService. The reference solution, however, uses a different field type (Set<Person>) and changes the constructor accordingly. This mismatch between template and solution (and the explicit 'do not change' note) is a structural inconsistency that may confuse students comparing their work to the solution or interpreting the rule about not changing attributes.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute declaration consistent across template and solution and align with the problem note. Either (A) keep the attribute as List<Person> in the solution (and update its constructor accordingly) so it matches the template and the 'do not change' instruction, or (B) update the template (and the problem note) to use Set<Person> if using a Set is intended. Prefer preserving the template's List<Person> (or explicitly update the problem statement) to avoid confusing students who are instructed not to change PersonService attributes.

issues.description: Problem statement (Part 2, method-signature description) incorrectly refers to the callback parameter type as Consumer<List<Note>> when describing the PersonController methods. The template and solution PersonController methods use Consumer<List<Person>>. This mismatch (Note vs Person) is an unintended identifier naming inconsistency that can confuse students about the expected method signatures and the type of the internal list the consumer will receive.
issues.suggested_fix: In the problem statement (Part 2) change the text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> instead of Consumer<List<Note>> so it matches the template and solution method signatures and clarifies that the consumer receives the internal list of Person objects.
